elements.content: Four novel mixed-ligand metal−organic frameworks (MOFs), [Zn5(μ3-OH)2(BTA)2(tp)3] n (1), [Zn(BTA)(chdc)0.5] n (2), [Zn(BTA)(ap)0.5] n (3), and [Zn(BTA)(gt)0.5] n (4) (BTAH = benzotriazole, H2tp = terephthalic acid, H2chdc = 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid, H2ap = adipic acid, and H2gt = glutaric acid), have been synthesized by the reaction of zinc(II) chloride and BTAH with four different aromatic/aliphatic binary acids under similar hydrothermal conditions. All these compounds are fully structurally characterized by elemental analysis, IR, single-crystal X-ray crystallography, and the bulk new materials were further identified by X-ray powder diffraction. Their compositional stability and photoluminescence properties were further investigated to establish the structure−properties relationships. Structural analysis reveals that 1 is a scarcely reported eight-connected three-dimensional (3-D) self-penetrating MOF with pentanuclear zinc clusters as secondary building units (SBUs); 2 is a 3-D infinite network with empty 34-membered hexanuclear zinc(II) metallamacrocycle channels; 3 and 4 are 3-D meso-racemic coordination polymers with a one-dimensional Zn-BTA helix chain motif, in which alternative right- and left-hand helical chains are linked together via ap for 3 and gt for 4. The much higher compositional stability up to 436 °C and strong solid-state luminescence emissions suggest that 1−4 are good candidates for light emission materials.

All these compounds are fully structurally characterized by elemental analysis, IR, single-crystal X-ray crystallography, and the bulk new materials were further identified by X-ray powder diffraction. Their compositional stability and photoluminescence properties were further investigated to establish the structure-properties relationships. Structural analysis reveals that 1 is a scarcely reported eight-connected three-dimensional (3-D) self-penetrating MOF with pentanuclear zinc clusters as secondary building units (SBUs); 2 is a 3-D infinite network with empty 34-membered hexanuclear zinc(II) metallamacrocycle channels; 3 and 4 are 3-D meso-racemic coordination polymers with a one-dimensional Zn-BTA helix chain motif, in which alternative right- and left-hand helical chains are linked together via ap for 3 and gt for 4. The much higher compositional stability up to 436 °C and strong solid-state luminescence emissions suggest that 1-4 are good candidates for light emission materials.

elements.content: Four novel three-dimensional Zn-BTA-based metal−organic frameworks have been successfully prepared by incorporating binary aromatic/aliphatic acid co-ligands under the same hydrothermal conditions. Their structural diversity (eight-connected self-penetrating frameworks with pentanuclear zinc(II) clusters as SBU for 1, a porous polymer with an empty 34-membered channel for 2, and MOFs with one-dimensional Zn-BAT helical chains motifs for 3 and 4) is highly related to the spacers of dicarboxylate groups co-ligands. Good compositional stability, much limited solubility, and strong fluorescence properties of 1−4 consistently reveal that these compounds may be excellent candidates for potential photoactive materials.

Their structural diversity (eight-connected self-penetrating frameworks with pentanuclear zinc(II) clusters as SBU for 1, a porous polymer with an empty 34-membered channel for 2, and MOFs with one-dimensional Zn-BAT helical chains motifs for 3 and 4) is highly related to the spacers of dicarboxylate groups co-ligands. Good compositional stability, much limited solubility, and strong fluorescence properties of 1-4 consistently reveal that these compounds may be excellent candidates for potential photoactive materials.

elements.content: In recent years, construction of novel highly connected metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) with polynuclear metal clusters as secondary building units (SBUs) or with higher-order stranded helical structures have aroused a great deal of interest due to their intriguing structural diversities and potential applications as functional materials. Thus, a series of high-dimensional MOFs with aromatic multicarboxylate-bridged di-, tetra-, and even octanuclear zinc(II) clusters as SBUs have been rationally designed and constructed, exhibiting highly compositional stability, good gas storage, and photoluminescent properties. On the other hand, because of the fundamental role of the helicity in biology, Lah13 et al. have also successfully prepared many three-dimensional (3-D) helical coordination networks assembled via classical covalent bonds and weak intermolecular interactions as well as using hexanuclear manganese metallamacrocycle as a helical tecton. However, it should be noted that the rational synthesis of these attractive coordination polymers is still facing many challenges because of various uncontrollable factors dominating the formation process of the final products. Therefore, many new synthetic strategies such as using SBUs, controlling the hydrolysis of metal salts, or selecting long flexible ligands and so on, have been extensively applied, in which a mixed-ligand approach by the judicious choice of organic ligands has been proven to be one of most effective and important ways to construct these novel MOFs. Meanwhile, considering that many polynuclear zinc(II) compounds have exhibited promising luminescent properties, especially those ligands containing hetero-aromatic rings, they can effectively enhance the fluorescence emissions of coordination polymers and are currently of interest in the development of fluorescent materials. In our efforts to systematically investigate the coordination chemistry as well as to deeply understand the inherent correlation between the mixed-ligand and novel functional MOFs, in the present paper, the less investigated compound benzotriazole (BTAH) and popular binary aromatic/aliphatic acids (terephthalic acid, 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid, adipic acid, and glutaric acid) as mixed-ligands were chosen to construct novel MOFs with zinc(II) ions. The main reasons for choosing BTAH are due to the following considerations. First, as an attractive rigid multifunctional ligand, BTAH with a relatively large conjugate system composed of benzene and triazole rings is helpful for the formation of highly nuclear cluster. Second, the 1,2,3-triazole moiety can afford bridging coordination modes and potentially form the helical coordination network similar to previous imidazole or pyrazole compounds. As expected, four 3-D novel structure-related MOFs controlled by the spacers of dicarboxylate ligands, [Zn5(μ3-OH)2(BTA)2(tp)3] n (1), [Zn(BTA)(chdc)0.5] n (2), [Zn(BTA)(ap)0.5] n (3), and [Zn(BTA)(gt)0.5] n (4) (H2tp = terephthalic acid, H2chdc = 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid, H2ap = adipic acid, and H2gt = glutaric acid), have been successfully isolated and structurally characterized. The structure determinations indicated that 1 is a scarcely reported eight-connected self-penetrating framework based on pentanuclear zinc(II) clusters. 2−4 are 3-D infinite networks with empty 34-membered hexanuclear zinc(II) metallamacrocycle channels (for 2) and one-dimensional (1-D) Zn-BAT helical chains motif for 3 and 4, respectively. The compositional stability and luminescence properties were also investigated.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, construction of novel highly connected metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with polynuclear metal clusters as secondary building units (SBUs) or with higher-order stranded helical structures have aroused a great deal of interest due to their intriguing structural diversities and potential applications as functional materials. Thus, a series of high-dimensional MOFs with aromatic multicarboxylate-bridged di-, tetra-, and even octanuclear zinc(II) clusters as SBUs have been rationally designed and constructed, exhibiting highly compositional stability, good gas storage, and photoluminescent properties. On the other hand, because of the fundamental role of the helicity in biology, Lah13 et al. have also successfully prepared many three-dimensional (3-D) helical coordination networks assembled via classical covalent bonds and weak intermolecular interactions as well as using hexanuclear manganese metallamacrocycle as a helical tecton. However, it should be noted that the rational synthesis of these attractive coordination polymers is still facing many challenges because of various uncontrollable factors dominating the formation process of the final products. Therefore, many new synthetic strategies such as using SBUs, controlling the hydrolysis of metal salts, or selecting long flexible ligands and so on, have been extensively applied, in which a mixed-ligand approach by the judicious choice of organic ligands has been proven to be one of most effective and important ways to construct these novel MOFs. Meanwhile, considering that many polynuclear zinc(II) compounds have exhibited promising luminescent properties, especially those ligands containing hetero-aromatic rings, they can effectively enhance the fluorescence emissions of coordination polymers and are currently of interest in the development of fluorescent materials. In our efforts to systematically investigate the coordination chemistry as well as to deeply understand the inherent correlation between the mixed-ligand and novel functional MOFs, in the present paper, the less investigated compound benzotriazole (BTAH) and popular binary aromatic/aliphatic acids (terephthalic acid, 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid, adipic acid, and glutaric acid) as mixed-ligands were chosen to construct novel MOFs with zinc(II) ions. The main reasons for choosing BTAH are due to the following considerations. First, as an attractive rigid multifunctional ligand, BTAH with a relatively large conjugate system composed of benzene and triazole rings is helpful for the formation of highly nuclear cluster. Second, the 1,2,3-triazole moiety can afford bridging coordination modes and potentially form the helical coordination network similar to previous imidazole or pyrazole compounds. As expected, four 3-D novel structure-related MOFs controlled by the spacers of dicarboxylate ligands, [Zn5(μ3-OH)2(BTA)2(tp)3] n  (1), [Zn(BTA)(chdc)0.5] n  (2), [Zn(BTA)(ap)0.5] n  (3), and [Zn(BTA)(gt)0.5] n  (4) (H2tp = terephthalic acid, H2chdc = 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid, H2ap = adipic acid, and H2gt = glutaric acid), have been successfully isolated and structurally characterized. The structure determinations indicated that 1 is a scarcely reported eight-connected self-penetrating framework based on pentanuclear zinc(II) clusters. 2-4 are 3-D infinite networks with empty 34-membered hexanuclear zinc(II) metallamacrocycle channels (for 2) and one-dimensional (1-D) Zn-BAT helical chains motif for 3 and 4, respectively. The compositional stability and luminescence properties were also investigated.

elements.content: Materials. All reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. Doubly deionized water was used for the conventional synthesis. Elemental analyses of carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen were carried out with a CE-440 (Leeman-Labs) analyzer. Fourier transform (FT) IR spectra (KBr pellets) were taken on an AVATAR-370 (Nicolet) spectrometer in the range 4000−400 cm-1 region. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were carried out on Shimadzu simultaneous DTG-60A compositional analysis instrument from room temperature to 800 °C under N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 5 °C/min. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) data were recorded on a Rigaku D/max-2500 diffractometer at 60 kV and 300 mA for Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å), with a scan speed of 2 deg/min and a step size of 0.02° in 2θ. The calculated XRPD patterns based on the single-crystal diffraction data were produced by Mercury 1.3 software, available from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center. Fluorescence spectra of the polycrystalline powder samples were performed on a Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer (Varian) equipped with a xenon lamp and quartz carrier at room temperature.

Experimental Section

 Materials. All reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. Doubly deionized water was used for the conventional synthesis. Elemental analyses of carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen were carried out with a CE-440 (Leeman-Labs) analyzer.  Fourier transform (FT) IR spectra (KBr pellets) were taken on an AVATAR-370 (Nicolet) spectrometer in the range 4000-400 cm-1 region. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were carried out on Shimadzu simultaneous DTG-60A compositional analysis instrument from room temperature to 800 °C under N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 5 °C/min. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) data were recorded on a Rigaku D/max-2500 diffractometer at 60 kV and 300 mA for Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å), with a scan speed of 2 deg/min and a step size of 0.02° in 2θ. The calculated XRPD patterns based on the single-crystal diffraction data were produced by Mercury 1.3 software, available from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center. Fluorescence spectra of the polycrystalline powder samples were performed on a Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer (Varian) equipped with a xenon lamp and quartz carrier at room temperature.

Synthesis of Complexes. [Zn 5 (μ 3 -OH) 2 (BTA) 2 (tp) 3 ] n (1). A mixture of ZnCl2 (13.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), BTAH (0.06 mg, 0.05 mmol), H2tp (8.3 mg, 0.05 mmol), and water (10 mL) was placed in a stainless steel vessel (20 mL). The pH of the mixture was carefully adjusted to 8.0 by slow addition of triethylamine. The mixture was heated to 140 °C within 24 h, kept at this temperature for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature at the rate of 5 °C·h-1. The colorless block-shaped single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained (yield:  28% based on Zn). Anal. Calcd for C36H22N6O14Zn5:  C, 39.69; H, 2.04; N, 7.71. Found:  C, 39.52; H, 2.11; N, 7.63. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3562w, 1586s, 1505m, 1390s, 1276m, 1183m, 900w, 824w, 743s.

elements.content: X-ray Data Collection and Structure Determinations. Diffraction intensities for complexes 1−4 were collected on Bruker APEX-II CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo−Kα radiation with radiation wavelength 0.71073 Å by using the φ−ω scan technique at ambient temperature. There was no evidence of crystal decay during data collection. Semiempirical absorption corrections were applied (SADABS), and the program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The organic hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically. The crystallographic data and selected bond lengths and angles for 1−4 are listed in Tables −5, respectively.

Syntheses and General Characterization. Complexes 1−4 were obtained as colorless crystalline materials by the reaction of BTAH and zinc(II) chloride with H2tp, H2chdc, H2ap, or H2gt in aqueous medium in a molar ratio of 1:2:1, respectively. It is noteworthy that the weak basic pH values in the starting reaction solutions are essential to successfully prepare 1−4. Attempts to synthesize 1−4 in an acidic or neutral pH value failed. The reasons may be because the weak basic environments could facilitate BTAH deprotonation and make it easy to coordinate with zinc(II) ions, which was also consistent with single X-ray analysis. In addition, compounds 1−4 are air stable, insoluble in common organic solvents, and can retain their crystalline integrity at ambient conditions for a considerable length of time. The phase purities of bulk samples were identified by powder X-ray diffraction analysis (see Figures S1−S4 in Supporting Information). It should be noted that for 2, the raw material of H2chdc used in the experiments is a mixture of both cis- and trans-conformations, but the 1,4-chdc dianion in compound 2 possesses only e,e-trans-conformation. Such selective coordination has rarely been observed in the process of assembly of coordination polymers and may provide possibilities for molecular recognition and separation after further exploration.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Syntheses and General Characterization. Complexes 1-4 were obtained as colorless crystalline materials by the reaction of BTAH and zinc(II) chloride with H2tp, H2chdc, H2ap, or H2gt in aqueous medium in a molar ratio of 1:2:1, respectively. It is noteworthy that the weak basic pH values in the starting reaction solutions are essential to successfully prepare 1-4. Attempts to synthesize 1-4 in an acidic or neutral pH value failed. The reasons may be because the weak basic environments could facilitate BTAH deprotonation and make it easy to coordinate with zinc(II) ions, which was also consistent with single X-ray analysis. In addition, compounds 1-4 are air stable, insoluble in common organic solvents, and can retain their crystalline integrity at ambient conditions for a considerable length of time. The phase purities of bulk samples were identified by powder X-ray diffraction analysis (see Figures S1-S4 in Supporting Information). It should be noted that for 2, the raw material of H2chdc used in the experiments is a mixture of both cis- and trans-conformations, but the 1,4-chdc dianion in compound 2 possesses only e,e-trans-conformation. Such selective coordination has rarely been observed in the process of assembly of coordination polymers and may provide possibilities for molecular recognition and separation after further exploration.

elements.content: In their IR spectra, the absorption bands resulting from the skeletal vibrations of the aromatic ring were observed in the 1400−1600 cm-1 region. The absence of the characteristics bands at 1715−1680 cm-1 indicates the complete deprotonation of the four carboxylic acids by triethylamine upon reaction with Zn ions, which is also consistent with the X-ray diffraction results. In addition, the most definitive feature in the four composite spectra is the presence of strong carboxylate stretching frequencies, which is well correlated with the binding modes of the carboxylate groups. In 1, the peaks appearing at 1586 and 1390 cm-1 are ascribed to the asymmetric and symmetry stretching vibrations of carboxylate groups. In the case of 2, they were observed at 1541 and 1434 cm-1, respectively. For 3 and 4, the characteristic peaks occur at 1538 (3), 1548 cm-1 (4) for asymmetric carboxylate stretching frequencies and at 1442, 1409 (3), 1454, 1408 cm-1 (4) for symmetric stretching of carboxylate groups. The large separations ranging from 107 to 196 cm-1 between νas(COO-) and νs(COO-) for 1−4 suggest the existence of a bridging dimonodentate mode of the carboxylate group, which is also confirmed by single-crystal structure analysis.

elements.content: Structure Descriptions of Complexes 1 − 4. [Zn 5 (μ 3 -OH) 2 (BTA) 2 (tp) 3 ] n (1). As shown in Figure a, X-ray analysis reveals that 1 contains three crystallographically independent Zn(II) centers (Zn1, Zn2, and Zn3), which are linked via one μ3-OH group to form one [Zn3(μ3-OH)] core. Zn1 is six-coordinated to four carboxylate oxygen atoms from four tp ligands and two μ3-OH groups, forming a slightly distorted octahedral coordination polyhedron. Zn2 and Zn3 have similar coordination environments and are both four-coordinated in a tetrahedral geometry to two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two tp dianions, one μ3-OH group, and one BTA triazole nitrogen atom. Although all the Zn−O bond distances are comparable to those documented values in the previous literature (Table ), the average Zn1−O bond length (2.084 Å) is slightly longer than those of Zn2−O (1.962 Å) and Zn3−O (1.949 Å). Both carboxylate groups in the tp ligand adopt a bridging dimonodentate coordination mode to link four Zn(II) centers together, and deprotonated BTA acts as a bidentate μ1,3-bridging ligand via 1,3-N atoms to join two neighboring Zn(II) centers.

elements.content: In 1, Zn2c and Zn3c are related to Zn2 and Zn3 by the symmetry-generated code (C:  −x + 2, −y + 2, −z + 1). Zn1 links Zn2, Zn3, Zn2c, and Zn3c via two μ3-OH groups, forming an unique pentanuclear [Zn5(μ3-OH)2 ]cluster. The pentanuclear zinc cluster can also be considered as two [Zn3(μ3-OH)] cores sharing a Zn1 vertex. It is notable that the five zinc(II) centers within the pentanuclear cluster are strictly coplanar. The nonbonding Zn1···Zn2, Zn1···Zn3, and Zn2···Zn3 distances are 3.338, 3.353, 3.359 Å, respectively, which is considerably shortened by the presence of Zn−O−Zn linkage. Each pentanuclear zinc(II) cluster in 1 is 10-coordinated to eight neighboring clusters via six bis-dimonodentate bridging μ4-tp ligands and four μ2-BTA ligands to extend into an infinite 3-D MOF (Figure b). The Zn1···Zn1 distances of neighboring pentanuclear clusters linked by tp carboxylate groups are 11.396, 11.410, 15.942 Å, respectively, which are much longer than those linked via BTA triazole N atoms (9.277 Å). Compared with the previously reported compound [Zn5(μ3-OH)2(tp)4(phen)2] n , much higher linkage numbers up to 10 (four BTAs and six bis-dimonodentate tps) was observed in 1, although such short BTA bridges should have a large spatial steric hindrance.

elements.content: Topologically, when the pentanuclear zinc(II) cluster is treated as a single node, tp and BTA as two different connectors, the structure of 1 can be simplified into a 3-D network sustained by irregular eight-connected nodes (two parallel BTA ligands linking the same neighboring pentanuclear cluster can be considered as a connector). Further analysis indicates that tp connectors link pentanuclear zinc SBUs into two identical interpreting six-connected α-Po-type structures, and then BTA connectors link the two α-Po-type structures to form a novel eight-connected 3-D MOF (Figure c). According to the self-penetrating topological definition proposed by Batten and Robson, as shown in Figure c,d, the two shortest four-member cycles (purple and red four-member cycles) in 1 are catenated, and therefore the topological structure of 1 can be classified as a eight-connected 3-D self-penetrating MOF. To our best knowledge, only a few examples involved in eight-connected 3-D self-penetrating MOFs are reported until now, which could help us deeply understand the nature of coordination polymer frameworks and better design functional materials.

elements.content: [Zn(BTA)(chdc) 0.5 ] n (2). Compound 2 crystallizes in the P2(1)/c space group, and there only exists one crystallographically independent zinc(II) center in the asymmetric unit. Each zinc(II) center is four-coordinated to two nitrogen atoms from two different BTA ligands and two oxygen atoms from two separate bridging dimonodentate carboxylate groups. The Zn−O and Zn−N distances are in the region of 1.965−1.983 Å (Table ) and exhibit a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry (Figure a). Each deprotonated BTA joins zinc(II) centers through a μ1,3-bidentate bridging mode to form a 1-D twisted Zn-BTA zigzag chain along the crystallographic c-axis. The neighboring Zn···Zn separations are 5.692(0) Å, and the interplane angle of two BTAs around the same zinc(II) ion is 79.395(3)°, leading to the formation of a twisted Z-shaped chain (Figure b). Both carboxylate groups of chdc anion consistently adopt a bridging dimonodentate binding mode, which joined those of 1-D Z-shaped chains together and further extended into bc and ab planes, respectively. In the bc plane, the 34-membered rings consisting of six zinc(II) centers, two chdc, and four BTA anions are found and further stacked together by the coordination of the residual two carboxylate oxygen atoms with zinc(II) ions and exhibit empty channels along the crystallographic a-axis with an interlayer distance of 4.81 Å. Similarly, in the ab plane, 18-membered rings consisting of two zinc(II) ions and two chdc ligands are also observed (Figure c).

elements.content: [Zn(BTA)(ap) 0.5 ] n (3) and [Zn(BTA)(gt) 0.5 ] n (4). The overall structure of 3 and 4 are highly similar except that 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic P2(1)/c space group, while 4 crystallizes in the higher symmetry orthorhombic Pbcn space group. The space group difference is interesting and scarcely reported, which should be ascribed to the length difference of alkane spacers between two carboxylate groups in 3 and 4. Because of the analogous structure of the two complexes, we will restrict our descriptions herein to complex 3 and only mention pertinent points for complex 4 where appropriate (see Figure S5 in Supporting Information).

elements.content: Similar to complex 2, the sole crystallographically independent Zn1 center in 3 is also four-coordinated to two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two ap ligands and two BTA triazole nitrogen atoms (Figure a). Interestingly, although the deprotonated BTA ligands also adopt a μ1,3-bidentate bridging mode linking the neighboring Zn(II) ions, the 1-D helical chain array along the [010] direction was finally observed and is different from the twisted zigzag chain of 2 (Figure b). This mainly resulted from the relative position of BTA ligands located at coordinated tetrahedron of the zinc(II) ion. In 3 and 4, the bond angle of N1−Zn−N3 and the interplane angle of two adjacent BTA is 122.08(6)° and 46.235(5)°, respectively (119.30(8)° and 53.418(5)° for 4).

elements.content: Since all the carboxylate groups in 1−4 display the sole bridging dimonodentate coordination mode and BTA consistently exhibits μ1,3-bridging mode via 1,3-N atoms (see Scheme S1 in the Supporting Information), the significant structural variation of the four complexes obtained under the same conditions should be due to the different nature of spacers of the binary carboxylate ligands and spatial orientation of mixed ligands. Aromatic tp ligands with a rigid skeleton could act as connectors and help to induce pentanuclear zinc(II) clusters to aggregate, while flexible ap, gt, and chdc anions act as pillars, linking helical and Z-shaped chains into infinite 3-D frameworks. In particular, the relative position around the metal ion can result in the different structural motifs such as helical and Z-shaped chains.

elements.content: Compositional Stability of the New MOFs. Thermogravimetric experiments were conducted to explore the compositional stability of 1−4, since it is an important parameter for MOFs materials (see Figure S6−S9 in Supporting Information). The TGA curve of 1 indicates that only one weight loss stage exists in the region of 467−528 °C (peak at 479 °C), accompanying two consecutive exothermic peaks. The weight loss at this stage is observed to be 62.91%, corresponding to the decomposition of deprotonated BTA and tp anions (calculated 62.65%). The remaining ZnO fragment is stable upon further heating until it ends at 800 °C. For the 3-D channel network of 2, the sole weight loss observed began at 519 °C and rapidly ended at 548 °C with an obviously exothermic effect. The total weight loss of this process is calculated to be 69.25%, which should be assigned to the simultaneous decompositions of organic BTA and chdc anions (calculated 69.70%). The TGA curves of 3 and 4 are much similar, probably due to their analogue's structural nature. The organic linkers in 3 and 4 began to release progressively, leading to a weight loss of 68.68% in the 436−487 °C range for 3 (67.26%, 445−500 °C for 4) and the leaving ZnO fragment as the final product. No remarkable changes were observed upon further heating of the sample to 800 °C. Thus, the generally higher decomposition temperature (>400 °C) for complexes 1−4, especially for 2, indicate that the 3-D mixed-ligand Zn(II) MOFs are good candidates for materials applications.

elements.content: Solid-State Fluorescence Spectroscopy. To examine the luminescent properties of the d10 metal complexes, the solid-state fluorescence spectra of 1−4 at room temperature are depicted in Figure . The intense emissions are observed at 348 nm (λex = 260 nm) for 1, 380 nm (λex = 287 nm) for 2, 360 nm (λex =264 nm) for 3, and 358 nm (λex = 265 nm) for 4. To understand the nature of the emission spectra, the luminescence properties of the free BTAH and H2tp ligands under the same conditions were recorded for comparison (see Figure S10−S11 in Supporting Information). The BTAH and H2tp ligands exhibit emission bands at 378 and 387 nm upon excitation at 278 and 262 nm, respectively, while those of aliphatic carboxylic ligands are observed without emission bands in the range of 400−800 cm-1. Therefore, the emissions of 1−4 may be assigned to intraligand fluorescent emission. The enhancement of luminescence may be attributed to ligand chelation to the metal center, which effectively increases the rigidity of the coordination polymers and reduces the loss of energy by radiationless decay. Notably, the slight shifts of the emission bands for 1−4 relative to the free BTAH and H2ap ligands are attributed to both the deprotonation of the BTAH/H2ap and the chelating coordination action of the carboxylate anion and BTA ion to Zn (II) ions. The slight shift between the bands of 3 and 4 may be derived from the slight coordination environment difference of metal ions, which is related to space group symmetry differences between 3 and 4.

elements.content: In conclusion, four novel 3-D Zn-BTA-based MOFs have been successfully synthesized and fully structurally characterized by incorporating binary aromatic/aliphatic acid co-ligands under the same hydrothermal conditions. Their structural diversity (eight-connected self-penetrating frameworks with pentanuclear zinc(II) clusters as SBU for 1, porous polymer with empty 34-memembered channel for 2 and MOFs with 1-D Zn-BAT helical chains motif for 3 and 4) are highly related to the spacers of dicarboxylate groups co-ligands. Good compositional stability, much limited solubility, and strong fluorescence properties of 1−4 consistently reveal that these compounds may be excellent candidates for potential photoactive materials, which also encourage us to extend our relevant investigations by a mixed-ligand synthetic strategy to explore new functional solid materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, four novel 3-D Zn-BTA-based MOFs have been successfully synthesized and fully structurally characterized by incorporating binary aromatic/aliphatic acid co-ligands under the same hydrothermal conditions. Their structural diversity (eight-connected self-penetrating frameworks with pentanuclear zinc(II) clusters as SBU for 1, porous polymer with empty 34-memembered channel for 2 and MOFs with 1-D Zn-BAT helical chains motif for 3 and 4) are highly related to the spacers of dicarboxylate groups co-ligands. Good compositional stability, much limited solubility, and strong fluorescence properties of 1-4 consistently reveal that these compounds may be excellent candidates for potential photoactive materials, which also encourage us to extend our relevant investigations by a mixed-ligand synthetic strategy to explore new functional solid materials.

cln_elements.content:
Synthesis of Complexes. [Zn 5 (μ 3 -OH) 2 (BTA) 2 (tp) 3 ] n (1). A mixture of ZnCl2 (13.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), BTAH (0.06 mg, 0.05 mmol), H2tp (8.3 mg, 0.05 mmol), and water (10 mL) was placed in a stainless steel vessel (20 mL). The pH of the mixture was carefully adjusted to 8.0 by slow addition of triethylamine. The mixture was heated to 140 °C within 24 h, kept at this temperature for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature at the rate of 5 °C·h-1. The colorless block-shaped single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained (yield:  28% based on Zn). Anal. Calcd for C36H22N6O14Zn5:  C, 39.69; H, 2.04; N, 7.71. Found:  C, 39.52; H, 2.11; N, 7.63. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3562w, 1586s, 1505m, 1390s, 1276m, 1183m, 900w, 824w, 743s.

[Zn(BTA)(chdc) 0.5 ] n (2). The colorless block single crystals of 2 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained by adopting the procedure similar to 1 only with the use of H2chdc instead of H2tp. Yield:  52% based on Zn. Anal. Calcd for C10H9N3O2Zn:  C, 44.72; H, 3.38; N, 15.65. Found:  C, 44.58; H, 3. 66; N, 15.82. IR (KBr, cm−1):  3782w, 2912w, 2850w, 1541s, 1434s, 1298m, 1273m, 1167ms, 928w, 742s, 471w.

[Zn(BTA)(ap) 0.5 ] n (3). The colorless block single crystals of 3 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained by adopting the procedure similar to 1 only with the use of H2ap instead of H2tp. Yield:  43% based on Zn. Anal. Calcd for C9H8N3O2Zn:  C, 42.30; H, 3.16; N, 16.44. Found:  C, 42.41; H, 3.20; N, 16.53. IR (KBr, cm−1):  1538s, 1442s, 1409s, 1358m, 1277m, 1162s, 747s.

[Zn(BTA)(gt) 0.5 ] n (4). The colorless block single crystals of 4 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained by adopting the procedure similar to 1 only with the use of H2gt instead of H2tp. cln_elements.content: Compositional Stability of the New MOFs. Thermogravimetric experiments were conducted to explore the compositional stability of 1−4, since it is an important parameter for MOFs materials (see Figure S6−S9 in Supporting Information). The TGA curve of 1 indicates that only one weight loss stage exists in the region of 467−528 °C (peak at 479 °C), accompanying two consecutive exothermic peaks. The weight loss at this stage is observed to be 62.91%, corresponding to the decomposition of deprotonated BTA and tp anions (calculated 62.65%). The remaining ZnO fragment is stable upon further heating until it ends at 800 °C. For the 3-D channel network of 2, the sole weight loss observed began at 519 °C and rapidly ended at 548 °C with an obviously exothermic effect. The total weight loss of this process is calculated to be 69.25%, which should be assigned to the simultaneous decompositions of organic BTA and chdc anions (calculated 69.70%). The TGA curves of 3 and 4 are much similar, probably due to their analogue's structural nature. The organic linkers in 3 and 4 began to release progressively, leading to a weight loss of 68.68% in the 436−487 °C range for 3 (67.26%, 445−500 °C for 4) and the leaving ZnO fragment as the final product. No remarkable changes were observed upon further heating of the sample to 800 °C. Thus, the generally higher decomposition temperature (>400 °C) for complexes 1−4, especially for 2, indicate that the 3-D mixed-ligand Zn(II) MOFs are good candidates for materials applications.
